newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian stocks finish higher in day of quiet trade.
newsitem.headline: Indian stocks finish higher in day of quiet trade.

text.p: ** (1200 GMT) - Indian shares end with small gains on
Friday after a weak start, SBI leads rally
** Trade largely operator-driven, low volumes
** Bombay share index up 19.85 pts, or 0.52 pct, at
** National exchange index up 2.20 pts at 1,069.40
** Foreign funds buyers in select stocks -- traders
** Delhi share index gains 1.58 points to 797.67, Madras
2.78 pts to 3,658.51 and Calcutta 0.34 pts to 107.39
Indian shares, led by State Bank of India, closed higher on the Bombay exchange on Friday.
The market started weakly, but underlying trends were masked by end-of-week position squaring.
"It was a dull market. Trade was mostly speculator-driven," said Ketan Jhaveri, chief dealer at Bombay's Kotak Securities, the Indian affiliate of Goldman Sachs.
"Buying interest was centred on select blue chips including IPCL, Mahindra & Mahindra, BSES and ONGC."
SBI jumped 8.50 rupees from a 306.50 low to end with a net gain of 5.75 at 314.75 and traded over six million shares.
Traders did not attach any particular reason to the rise and said hectic buying by some operators pushed up SBI.
"The rally in this market-favourite stock helped perk up sentiment," said an equities dealer at a foreign brokerage.
Foreign funds were bidders in blue chips, but trading volumes were low, traders said.
U.S. investment bank Merrill Lynch said on Friday it was moving funds into Indian stock markets from Latin America.
The performance of Indian equities during the next six to nine months could surprise investors, Merrill said in a strategy report titled "As We See It: India on Full Throttle".
"We are moving funds into the market at the expense of Latin America," Merrill said.
"Regionally, we think Korea and Thailand will be important stories going out a year, but there may be a near-term opportunity cost of not exploiting the Indian story."
But Paribas Capital Markets urged investors to be cautious on Indian stocks if Bombay's index touched 3900-4000 points.
The market is waiting for a crucial Sunday meeting of former finance minister P. Chidambaram's Tamil Maanila Congress (TMC).
The TMC will meet to decide if it wants to rejoin the United Front government after pulling out a week ago.
-- Anshuman Daga, Bombay equities desk +91-22-265 9000
